function.description: User can enter their weight.
User can select weight units (e.g., kg, lbs).
User can enter their height.
User can select height units (e.g., cm, in, ft-in).
User can click a button to calculate their BMI.
The calculated BMI value is displayed to the user.
User sees their BMI category (e.g., Underweight, Normal weight, Overweight, Obese).
User can clear the input fields to perform a new calculation.
The calculator shows a helpful message if the user enters non-numeric or invalid values.
The calculator layout adjusts correctly to different screen sizes (desktop, tablet, mobile).
The calculator automatically handles unit conversion (e.g. between cm and inches) if needed.
User can choose the base currency from a dropdown list of available currencies.
User can choose the target currency from a dropdown list of available currencies.

User can see the converted amount in the target currency, displayed clearly.
User can quickly swap the base and target currencies with a single button click.
User can see the current exchange rate between the selected base and target currencies.

function.function: View simulated historical exchange rate graph
function.description: User can view the simulated historical exchange rate data presented in a graph with configurable time range(e.g. 1 week, 1 month, 1 year).
The application gracefully handles non-numeric input in the amount field (e.g., displays an error message).
User can know when is the exchange rate last updated.

User can add a new to-do item to the list.
User can modify the text/description of an existing task.
User can remove a task from the list.
User can check a box or similar control to indicate a task is finished.
User can uncheck a box or to indicate a completed task is not finished.
User can see all current to-do items in a list format.
User can assign a priority level (e.g., High, Medium, Low) to a task.
User can set a due date and/or time for a task.
User can add the detail description/note.
User can choose to view only 'Completed', 'Incomplete' or 'All' tasks.
User can filter tasks to show only those with a specific priority level.
User can filter to show tasks due today, this week, or within a custom date range.
User can input a search term, matching tasks will be filtered and shown in the list.
User can sort tasks alphabetically, by due date, by priority, or by creation date.
User can see all details of a task, including description, priority, due date, and any subtasks.
User can modify any of the task details from this view.
User can create smaller subtasks within a larger task.
User can mark individual subtasks as complete.
User can delete the subtasks from the list.
User can easily navigate back to the main task list view.
User can see a chart (e.g., pie chart or bar graph) showing the proportion of completed vs. incomplete tasks.
User can see a chart showing the distribution of tasks across different priority levels.

The calendar should display the current month by default.
User should be able to easily navigate to the previous or next month using buttons or swipe gestures.
User can select a specific month and year to view.
The calendar should clearly display the days of the week (Sun, Mon, Tue, etc.).
The current day should be visually highlighted.
Clicking on a day should show a list of events for that day (if any).
Days with scheduled events should have a visual indicator (e.g., a dot, different color).
Option to display week numbers alongside the dates. (Toggleable)
Be able to switch views between Month, Week, Day, and (optionally) Year.
User should be able to add a new event by clicking on a day or using an 'Add Event' button.
User can enter a title for the event.

function.function: Set Event Start/End Date and Time
function.description: User can specify the start and end date and time for the event.
User can mark an event as an all-day event.
User can specify the location of the event.
User can add a description or notes to the event.
User can set reminders for the event (e.g., 1 hour before, 1 day before).
User can set the event to recur (daily, weekly, monthly, yearly).
User can choose a color to categorize the event visually.
The event should be saved and appear on the calendar.
User should be able to modify all details of an existing event.
User should be able to delete an event.
User should be able to duplicate an existing event.
The Day view should display an hourly breakdown of the day.
Events should be displayed in their respective time slots.
The duration of each event should be visually represented.

function.function: Easily Create Events within Time Slots
function.description: Clicking on an empty time slot should allow the user to quickly create an event starting at that time.

function.function: Navigate to previous and next day.
function.description: Allow users to move to the previous and next day with buttons/swiping

function.function: Show Hourly Schedule for Each Day
function.description: Each day of the week should show an hourly schedule.
Events should be displayed within their corresponding time slots for each day.
The duration of each event should be visually represented.

function.function: Easily Create Events within Time Slots
function.description: Clicking on an empty time slot should allow for quick event creation.

function.function: Navigate to previous and next week.
function.description: Allow users to move to the previous and next week with buttons/swiping
User can change the calendar's time zone.
User can customize the date and time format.
User can choose which day is the start of the week (Sunday or Monday).
User can specify a default reminder time for new events.
User can set the default calendar view (Month, Week, Day).
User should have granular control of notification settings(enable/disable, sound, type, etc.)
Allow User can choose between a dark or light theme for the application.
User can search for events by keyword (title, description, location).
User can filter search results (e.g., by date range, event color).
Search results should be displayed in a clear and organized list.
Start a conversation with the chatbot by typing a message or clicking a suggested prompt.
The chatbot should understand questions and requests phrased in everyday language, not just specific keywords.
Receive clear and concise answers directly related to my initial query.
See examples of how the chatbot can be used in different scenarios (e.g., customer service, information retrieval, task automation).
Easily find information about the chatbot's main capabilities and benefits.
Easily locate pricing information and plans, if the chatbot is a paid service.
See a clear history of my conversation with the chatbot, with distinct messages from me and the bot.
The chatbot should remember previous messages in the current conversation and use them to understand the context of follow-up questions.
Ask multi-part questions or questions that require reasoning and receive a coherent answer.
If my question is unclear, the chatbot should ask clarifying questions instead of guessing.
Receive suggestions for related questions or topics that might be of interest.
Receive responses in various formats as appropriate, such as lists, tables, links to resources, or short summaries.
Be able to change the topic of conversation without confusing the chatbot.
If the chatbot doesn't understand, it should politely indicate so and offer to try again or rephrase the question, rather than giving a nonsensical answer.
If the chatbot supports personalization, it should remember my preferences and tailor responses accordingly (e.g., preferred language, tone).
Be able to end the conversation and receive a confirmation or summary if needed.
Quickly search for answers to common questions using keywords.
Navigate through FAQs organized by topic or category.
Easily find contact information or a form to reach out for additional help if the FAQs don't answer my question.
Explanations in the help section should be clear and easy to understand, avoiding overly technical language.
Access step-by-step guides to help troubleshoot common issues.
See a list of platforms and services the chatbot can integrate with (e.g., Slack, CRM, email).
Learn how each integration can improve my workflow or provide added value.
Find clear and concise instructions on how to set up each integration.
Interact with a live demo of the chatbot to experience its capabilities firsthand.
Follow pre-defined scenarios to see how the chatbot handles specific tasks or situations.
Explore and use all the main features presented on the chatbot
See a brief overview of the app's purpose and benefits.

Employees and administrators can securely log in using their credentials (username and password).
Users can request a password reset if they forget their password.
Employees can view a list of all their submitted claims, including their status (Approved, Rejected, Pending).
Employees can create and submit new expense claims.
Employees can categorize their claims under Travel Expenses, Labor Expenses, Management Expenses, or Equipment Expenses.
Employees can enter the amount, description, and date of the expense.
Employees can attach supporting documents (e.g., receipts, invoices) to their claims.
Employees can submit their completed claim for review and approval.
Allow employees to edit claims that are still in 'Pending' status.
Employees can view the details of a specific claim.
Administrators can see a list of all pending claims awaiting approval.
Administrators can view the details of each claim, including the amount, description, category, date and supporting documents.
Administrators can approve claims.
Administrators can reject claims.
Administrators can provide a reason for rejecting a claim (this reason should be visible to the employee).
Administrators can filter claims by status (Approved, Rejected, Pending), employee, date range, and expense category.
Administrators can search for claims by keywords(claim ID, employee name, etc.).
Administrators can view all historical claim records.
Administrators can set budget limits for each expense category (Travel, Labor, Management, Equipment) for specific periods (e.g., monthly, quarterly, annually).
Administrators can view a comparison of the budgeted amount versus the actual spending for each expense category.
Administrators can generate reports on spending, budget utilization, and other relevant financial data.
Administrators can view remaining budget of all subjects.
Administrators can see the history of budget changes and adjustments.
Data should be presented with charts/graphs for easy analysis.
Administrators can export budget and spending data in various formats (e.g., CSV, Excel, PDF).
Set alerts to notify administrator when budget is approaching or exceeding limit
Create a new customer record with name, birthday, age (automatically calculated from birthday), sex, company, and phone number.
Modify the details of an existing customer record, including name, birthday, sex, company, and phone number. Age should update automatically if birthday is changed.
Remove a customer record from the system.
Display all details of a selected customer, including their preferred products and purchase history.
Find customers based on name, phone number, or company.
Display a list of all customers, with options to sort by name, company, or last purchase date.
Associate one or more preferred products with a customer.
Disassociate a preferred product from a customer.
See a list of products that a customer has marked as preferred.
Create a new product record with name, category, and recommended price.
Modify the details of an existing product, including name, category, and recommended price.
Remove a product record from the system.
Display all details of a selected product.
Find products by name or category.
Display a list of all products, sortable by name, category, or price.
Create a new purchase record with date and time, selected product, selected customer, quantity, and total amount (automatically calculated).
Modify the details of an existing purchase record, including date/time, product, customer, quantity, and amount.
Remove a purchase record from the system.
Display all details of a selected purchase record.
Find purchase records by date range, product, or customer.
Display a list of all purchase records, with options to sort by date, product, or customer.
Generate a report showing total sales revenue over a specified time period (e.g., daily, weekly, monthly, yearly).
Generate a report showing the sales quantity and revenue for each product over a specified time period.
Generate a report showing the sales quantity and revenue for each product category over a specified time period.
View a report of the purchase history for a specific customer, including dates, products, quantities, and amounts.
Generate a report listing the top customers based on total purchase amount over a specified time period.
Generate a report listing the top-selling products based on quantity sold or revenue generated over a specific period.
Show a report indicating the popularity of products based on how many customers list them as preferred.
Group customers based on similar purchase patterns (e.g., frequent buyers, high-value buyers, one-time buyers).
The page should display the text 'Hello, World!'.
The page should load without any errors.
The browser tab title should appropriately reflect the page content (e.g., 'Hello World', 'My Website - Hello').
Screen readers are able to read text.
The main page should prominently display a single button labeled 'Jump to Hello World'.
Clicking the 'Jump to Hello World' button should navigate the user to the 'helloword' page.
The page should contain no other elements, text, or links besides the button.
The page must display a 'Hello World' message. The message should be easily visible.
